content.text: The word cocktail first appeared in print in 1806, described as a stimulating drink made from spirits, sugar, water, and bitters. At this stage, cocktails were simple, functional drinks, often consumed in the morning as tonics rather than for leisure.

These drinks focused on balance and consistency rather than presentation.

sections.heading: The Golden Age of Cocktails (Mid–Late 19th Century)

content.text: This period marked the rise of professional bartending. Bars became social hubs, and bartenders were respected craftsmen.

items: Introduction of ice as a standard ingredient
Use of fresh citrus and refined sugars

content.text: Many drinks created during this era remain foundations of modern cocktail culture.
Prohibition in the United States drastically changed cocktail culture.

items: Poor-quality spirits required strong flavors to mask defects
Increased use of citrus, sugar, and mixers
Migration of bartenders to Europe and Cuba

content.text: This era popularized many sweet, citrus-forward cocktails still served today.
After Prohibition ended, cocktail quality briefly recovered but later declined due to:
Many classic techniques and recipes were simplified or forgotten during this time.
A renewed interest in authenticity and quality brought cocktails back to their roots.

items: Bartending recognized as a skilled profession

content.text: Modern cocktail culture blends tradition with creativity, respecting history while encouraging innovation.
